context: [4] Therefore, the maintenance of a self-regulated loop in which the expression of TNF-Î± is perpetuated by the TNF-Î±-mediated basal activation of NF-ÎºB could play a major role in the survival and/or proliferation of tumor cells. [5] PDTC has been shown to be a potent and specific inhibitor of the NF-ÎºB-mediated expression of TNF-Î± . [6] Untreated AD10 cells exhibited a basal expression of TNF-Î±, which was enhanced by stimulation with exogenous TNF-Î± and subsequently inhibited by PDTC (Fig. 2 B). [7] Similarly, using the nitric oxide donor SNAP, we were able to completely abrogate the expression of endogenous TNF-Î± (Fig. 2 A). [8] In contrast, nitric oxide was unable to block the basal expression of endogenous TNF-Î± in the absence of exogenous stimulation. [9] These results strongly suggest the inhibitory role of nitric oxide on TNF-Î±-induced activation of NF-ÎºB and consequently resulting in the disruption of TNF-Î± gene expression. [1] TNF-Î± induces the generation of ROS that may serve as second messengers in the activation of divergent pathways related to the cell death processes .

llm_generation.summary: In this context, nitric oxide (NO) is discussed in relation to its inhibitory effects on TNF-α-induced activation of NF-κB, which is crucial for the expression of various genes, including those related to soluble NSF attachment protein activity. While the direct relationship between nitric oxide and soluble NSF attachment protein activity is not explicitly detailed, the modulation of TNF-α signaling by nitric oxide suggests a potential regulatory role that could influence soluble NSF attachment protein activity indirectly through the NF-κB pathway.
